race.name: WYO 131
race.tagline: Central Wyoming ultra-distance gravel through mountain and high desert.

vitals.aid_stations: Multiple aid stations for ultra distance

climate.description: High altitude with variable conditions. Wind and sun exposure.

terrain.primary: Wyoming mountain and high desert gravel
terrain.surface: Mix of mountain and high desert gravel roads. Significant elevation with remote wilderness setting.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional ultra-distance event. 131 miles is serious challenge but regional field and infrastructure.

biased_opinion.summary: WYO 131 offers a genuine ultra-distance challenge—131 miles through Wyoming mountain and high desert terrain. It's a well-organized regional ultra event with good support, but the field is regional and it's remote central Wyoming. The adventure of riding through Wind River Range country is the main appeal, along with the ultra-distance challenge.
strengths: Beautiful Wyoming mountain and desert scenery
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional ultra-distance gravel race with genuine Wyoming wilderness appeal. Worth it for Wyoming cyclists or those seeking an ultra-distance challenge in the Rockies. Not a destination race for distant travelers, but a good regional ultra event.

final_verdict.one_liner: Regional Wyoming ultra-distance through mountain and high desert.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Wyoming or the Rockies and want an ultra-distance challenge—yes, it's a well-organized event with genuine wilderness appeal. If you're traveling from far away—there are more prestigious ultra events elsewhere.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better ultra-distance: Unbound XL (Kansas), Dirty Kanza. For similar regional ultras: other Rocky Mountain ultra events.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Lander has basic lodging. Small city with limited options. Book early.
logistics.food: Small city with basic dining. Stock nutrition for ultra distance.
logistics.parking: Park at 405 Fremont St in early morning darkness (hence mandatory bike light)

history.origin_story: Ultra-distance gravel event in central Wyoming.

course_description.character: Mix of mountain and high desert terrain through Wyoming wilderness.

suffering_zones.label: First Third
suffering_zones.desc: 40 miles in, settling into ultra pace.

course_description.signature_challenge: 131-mile ultra-distance at high altitude through Wyoming wilderness.

guide_variables.race_terrain: Wyoming mountain and high desert gravel

non_negotiables.why: 131 miles requires extensive endurance base and ultra-distance preparation.
Racing at 6000-8000+ feet requires altitude acclimatization or preparation.
Ultra-distance success depends on conservative pacing and not going out too hard.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 131 miles of Wyoming mountain and high desert gravel.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional ultra-distance challenge through Wind River Range country.

logistics.explanation: Race-day packet pickup from 5:30-7:30 AM for a 6 AM start cuts it close for 131 miles. The course website warns riders are "RESPONSIBLE FOR YOUR OWN NAVIGATION" and that participants "MAY HAVE TO WAIT UNTIL A COURSE MARSHALL IS AVAILABLE" if picked up by sweepers. No airport, lodging, or parking details provided for remote Lander.

length.explanation: 131 miles with 10,000 feet of climbing delivered a 19-23% DNF rate across recent years—12 of 63 starters couldn't finish in 2025. Chris Mehlman's 7:04 course record versus back-of-pack times past 13 hours shows the full spectrum of suffering. Strict cutoffs at Hudson (8 AM), Highway 287 (12 PM), and Atlantic City (4 PM) actually matter. Among the longest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

technicality.explanation: The course features "top-tier gravel roads (no sketchy two-track here!)" described as "fast, flowy, and ridiculously fun." The roughest section comes at miles 60-90: "Extremely wash boarded and winds usually pick up. Keep your head down and just knock this section out." Endurance trumps technical bike handling through high desert terrain. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The Louis Lake Road climb reaches the high point of 9,576 feet at mile 109, where riders "question your decision to enter this race in the first place." From there begins "an amazing 22 mile descent back to Lander" including the "wicked fast descent" through Sinks Canyon switchbacks. 10,000 feet of total vertical spans desert to subalpine ecosystems. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score.

climate.explanation: September conditions create variability through the washboard middle section where "winds usually pick up" during the traditionally rough miles 60-90. The 6 AM lights-required start suggests weather window management at Wyoming altitude. Race warnings emphasize proper preparation for conditions spanning "vast sagebrush plateaus" to "subalpine terrain." Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Starting at 7,500 feet in Lander, riders climb to the high point of 9,576 feet at mile 109 in the Wind River Mountains. The course maintains sustained altitude exposure through "high alpine bliss" with "beautiful views into the Wind River Range" rather than brief elevation spikes. Mandatory gear includes extra thermal layers for subalpine conditions. Higher altitude racing, comparable to SBT GRVL.

adventure.explanation: The route delivers "131 miles of pure, untamed adventure" through towering Wyoming Hoodoos at mile 36.5 and the historic gold mining town of Atlantic City at mile 90. Riders traverse "everything from fast-rolling gravel to chunky, soul-crushing sections" before the "wicked, white-knuckle descent through Sinks Canyon State Park." Crew-accessible bail points when Wyoming backcountry exceeds capability.

prestige.explanation: Chris Mehlman's 7:04 course record and Caroline Weiler's 9:05 women's mark reflect a small competitive field without major pro presence. The race philosophy "Ride hard. Live easy. Wave often" emphasizes Wyoming authenticity over national recognition. Multi-distance options from 13 to 131 miles serve local community over elite competition building.

race_quality.explanation: The course earns its reputation with cutoffs that matter—19-23% DNF rates prove the difficulty. Aid Station 5 at Louis Lake restricts crew access "to avoid/reduce traffic passing the racers" on narrow mountain roads. Race-day-only packet pickup and the warning that riders "MAY HAVE TO WAIT" for course marshals keep execution from premium standards.

experience.explanation: Lander is "ranked as one of the best outdoor towns in America" at "the southern tip of the Wind River Range, just west of Jackson." The course spans ecosystems from Red Desert sagebrush to Wind River subalpine lakes with "5-star panoramic views." Post-race includes "beer and food waiting for you" though limited weather data leaves experience quality partly to chance.

community.explanation: The "Inspiration Ride" welcomes all bikes including e-bikes with "No excuses—you're not too young, too old, or too 'whatever-you-think-you-are' to roll with us!" Four distance options from 13 to 131 miles serve different rider levels. The tagline "Type-2 fun at its finest" embodies Wyoming backcountry community over competitive racing culture.

field_depth.explanation: The 131-mile field shows limited competitive depth with 52-63 starters and finish time spreads exceeding 6 hours from winner to 40th place. Elite times like Charlie Hagen's 8:08 in 2025 versus Chris Mehlman's 7:04 course record indicate variable year-to-year competition. Small overall participation despite the scenic Wind River Range setting. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Four distance options from the paved "Inspiration Ride" to the full 131-mile course serve different rider levels with dedicated e-bike divisions. The "Gateway to Gravel" 45-mile option targets newcomers while the full course delivers "pure, untamed adventure." Post-race includes local food and beer, though missing entry fee data makes cost-benefit analysis impossible.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $100-150. Mandatory gear includes SPOT tracker or Garmin inReach, waterproof layers, multiple spare tubes, and "butt butter" (mentioned twice in course descriptions) for the rough washboard sections. Remote Lander location requires travel planning without provided lodging details. The extensive recommended gear list suggests significant equipment expenses for Wyoming backcountry conditions. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
